captions.text:
Good morning, John, we are about to have gone
around the sun again. That's right, my next

Vlogbrothers video will be made in the year
2015. Over on SciShow, Michael Aranda just

gave us some of the science superlatives of
2014: the deepest diving whale ever recorded,

the most Earth-like planet, the highest CO2
emissions, and the warmest months ever recorded.

2014 has been a big year in science, but it's
also been a big year in general, so here on

Vlogbrothers where things are more general,
let's talk about some of the biggest, bestest,

superlative-est things that happened this
year.

First, with the very likely possibility that
this will have been the warmest year ever

recorded, and while we are an adaptable species,
and I do have a lot of faith in us, figuring

out how to grow all the food we need to grow
with water landing in different places than

it used to land, and protecting all of the
infrastructure we already have with new infrastructure
that's going to be very expensive... (groan).

But there's also good news. 2014 saw the youngest
ever recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize. Malala

Yousafzai's acceptance speech made me cry,
it probably will make you cry too if you watch

it, and it also gave me hope about some very
depressing, seemingly hopeless situations,

so that's -- and she's 17. What was I doing
when I was 17? I can't even talk about it.
I -- no.

It was also probably the best year ever to
be a nerd. Sherlock came back, Orphan Black

is awesome, we're getting new Star Wars movies
and new Star Trek movies, and new Avengers

movies, we had a new X-Men movie, new Doctor,
new Veronica Mars, new Cosmos. We landed a

probe on a comet, Curiosity realized that
it's definitely for sure roving around on

an ancient Martian lakebed, got a female Thor,
and a black Captain America. It's been a good
year.

I'll also venture to say that it's the first
year in decades when America broadly decided

that it had to confront its, you know, sort
of mass, like, racism. That's what it -- that's

-- yeah. Michael Brown, Eric Garner, John
Crawford, 12-year-old Tamir Rice, were all

killed by police officers and were all unarmed.
In and of itself, that's actually not unusual,

which is a sad thing to have to say. Unarmed
black men are shot and killed by police officers

every year. This isn't like a new explosion
of police shootings. What's different is all

of the Americans, mostly Americans of color,
who stood up and said that they have had enough,

and advanced a national dialogue about police
wearing body cameras, about the difficulties

of being a person of color in America, about
the systemic racism in the justice system.

These are problems that we've always had,
but that we haven't talked about for a long

time, like somehow racism went away after
segregation.

Discussions about systemic sexism were also
advanced, with Emma Watson's he-for-she speech

at the United Nations, and that video that
got like 30 million views of this woman just
walking around New York being harassed.

One final first for you: here in Missoula,
Montana we had our first same-sex marriage

at the courthouse, which just, I can't believe
it took so long, but it happened. As with

any year, there's been good and there's been
bad, and we talk more about the bad than about

the good, but maybe that will lead us to fighting
against the bad so that next year, in 2015,

there will be less of it, though I'm sure
the amount of it that we have is what we will
mostly talk about. Again. As always.

With help from some people on Twitter, I've
created a playlist of some of the most important

YouTube videos of 2014, including Emma Watson
and Malala's speeches, and CGP Grey talking

about why maybe in the future, jobs won't
exist. Should you be happy or sad? I'm not

sure. Everyone, thank you for another great
year here at Vlogbrothers, and John, I'll
see you on Tuesday.

comments.text:
It cannot have been the warmest year ever. It may have been the warmest 
year since we've started recording temperatures, but when the Vikings 
landed in America, they recorded in the Sagas that there was no frost. For 
the entire winter. In Labrador. Canada. Now, the Vikings weren't 
scientists, but they knew frost when they saw it. Climate change has 
happened before, and in a few decades, it will be all over, and we'll be 
back to "normal" again, if there is such a thing as normal. ps. I'm an 
environmental science major. ﻿

comments.text:
Ok, you're a genius Hank but what?! If I understood correctly the uprising 
was good and just. A. Michael Brown was carrying a weapon and was only 
killed after he bashed the officer's face in on the steering wheel. B. Is 
violence ever the answer? I mean, MLK was peacefully protesting, Michael 
Brown's father (biological)  thought that there shouldn't be violence but 
his step father and mother both rallied people together and burned all of 
the businesses in the area, not only white businesses but black too. Which 
meant it was, maybe, in the name of racial equality but it was really for 
violence and disorder. I agree there is a racism problem in the US and that 
these things made people reflect upon that but it didn't lead to anything 
good. It was only reinforcing the assumptions that blacks are violent and 
are always linked to crime, which they aren't.﻿

comments.author: El Masry

comments.text:
I'm not saying every police shooting is justified, but the vast majority 
are. The shooting of "unarmed black men" (one of which was a *seemingly* 
armed boy, and another very large and behaving in a threatening manner 
towards a police officer) was blown way out of proportion by the media and 
was treated with bias towards the "victims." (that is, those who were shot, 
even though the man behind the gun is often the victim) I encourage all 
people to research the facts, be skeptical of all reporting, and to 
interpret your own truths. Yes, unarmed black men were shot. But no, it 
wasn't JUST because of the color of their skin. Please stop playing the 
guilty white male, Hank. You're much too intelligent to believe everything 
the media says, and not give it a little bit of thought. Nerdfighteria is 
one of the few communities where you can speak your mind and display facts 
without getting the masses jumping to conclusions about what type of person 
you are. Thanks.﻿

comments.text:
You know, Emma Watson's HeForShe movement may be far from perfect, but a 
baby step is still a step, so instead of whining about it's flaws, be 
thankful that we're making some kind of progress, as miniscule as that 
might be. Start putting in your 2 cents, encourage people to open their 
minds, be nice. By sitting on your asses and whining y'all are hindering 
evolution. You need to understand it's basic motives, be logical about it 
and accept the fact that yes, this movement does have it's flaws, but it is 
a step in the right direction, and yes, nobody's perfect, but at least this 
person is trying. Come on, humanity, I'm losing faith in you really quickly 
at this point. How is it that we are simultaneously getting smarter and 
more ignorant at the same time? ﻿

white man said, "Colored people are not allowed here."
The black man turned around and stood up, he then said, "When I was born I 
was BLACK. When I grew up I was BLACK. When I am sick I'm BLACK. When I'm 
in the sun I'm BLACK. When I'm cold I'm BLACK. When I die I'll be BLACK. 
But you sir, when you were born you were PINK. When you grew up you were 
WHITE. When you're sick you're GREEN. When you're in the sun you're RED. 
When you're cold you're BLUE. When you die you'll be PURPLE. And you have 
the nerve to call ME colored." The black man sat back down and the white 
man walked away﻿

comments.author: Hailey Small

comments.text:
Can I ask a genuine question, Hank? What do you think of sexism that goes 
against men? A lot of people deny it exists, but even as a woman I have to 
admit that in a lot of matters (childcare, family matters and abuse in 
particular) men are discriminated against. But if one dares to say that men 
have any problems at all, tons of feminists will immediately call you a 
misogynist. I agree that women are victims of sexism, but I tend do think 
men's problems are largely ignored. I would actually really appreciate some 
input from you.

Side note: My girlfriend is MtF and as a guy in the public eye, she was 
treated very badly on the internet (mostly on pages where there's many 
women and very few men). Then, when she came out, she was suddenly received 
with much more openness and the mocking and poking fun at stopped.﻿

comments.author: Jordan Phillips

comments.text:
As much as I appreciate that this was a general video about the biggest 
global events in 2014, Hank, I really think it's a shame that you missed 
this opportunity to talk about all the abusers who were exposed in the 
YouTube community. This is something that affected so many of your viewers 
in a very real and very difficult-to-deal-wtih way this year, whether they 
were victims themselves or merely having to come to terms with finding out 
some of their favourite and most trusted icons are scumbags. Your 
viewership is, on the whole, very young, and they've looked to older 
YouTube content creators to give them an idea of how to react to this 
situation (and honestly I think as a whole the vlogbrothers' response on 
YouTube itself has been minimal, although I know you made some tumblr 
posts).
With more abuse coming to light every few months or even weeks, we need to 
keep talking about this, and I think it's a shame you haven't publicly done 
so yet. I mean, focusing on the positives here - the community HAS become 
stronger, and people HAVE stood by the victims, and conventions HAVE become 
safer, including VidCon! Your convention! Talk about that! And I see the 
"Sam Pepper Exposed" video in your playlist which, yes, is a great video, 
and talks about some very important topics related to sexual harassment.and 
assault, does focus more on the prank assaults rather than the private 
abuse that went on (and was covered up) for YEARS by many more people than 
just Pepper. Anyway, just my two cents, and I'm not sure how likely it is 
you'll see this - and maybe it's unrealistic to think you'll be making a 
video about this any time soon, as it seems clear that the vlogbrothers and 
most other "respected" channels seem keen to move on from all this 
uncomfortable talk about scandals. But I'm... Not gonna stop asking why 
there have been so few videos about this on major channels.Anyway. Happy 
new year!﻿

comments.author: vlogbrothers

comments.text:
2014 is the year where I stopped caring about racism, equality and bigotry.

Hotheaded "progressives" crawled out of the woodwork to shout down everyone 
who didn't agree with them and labeled people as bigots in a fit of 
hypocritical outrage.
Emma Watson, a person who has earned millions and is doing a nude scene in 
a movie told the men of the world to give women equal pay and not to 
objectify them, while offhandedly assuring them that "men's problems" would 
probably go away as well if only they set women before themselves.

Hank and John, I genuinly believe you do good work, but I also think you 
both have your heads so far up your asses that you don't see the bullshit 
reasoning from ridiculous "progressives", for what it is.

Despite that, I wish you and all the followers a happy new year.
If you wish to improve the world, start with yourselves, before worrying 
about how others behave. It's solid advice for *anyone*.﻿

comments.author: Manish Subramaniam

comments.text:
It makes me sad that the police abuse issue has been reduced to a race 
issue.  Race is not the problem, lack of accountability and a system that 
rewards people who behave in a reckless manner is the problem.  People who 
have limited power are the primary victims, and race can play into that. 
 Although so does poverty and mental illness (and mental illness plays into 
WAY more than race does).  But these are symptoms, not the issue itself. 
 If you break up a large overarching problem and only look at the symptoms, 
you will never find a cure, you will only ever shift who will be the next 
victim.  And, focusing so much on race, the most likely people who will 
lose out are the mentally ill, who are already shouldering a 
disproportionate degree of burden.  We shouldn't be telling people to be 
nicer to some voiceless minorities so that other voiceless minorities may 
suffer in even increased silence.  We should be standing up and saying the 
system is fundamentally flawed and must be fixed.﻿
comments.author: Melthornal
